        <title>The Vacation</title>
        <description><p>I situated myself in the premium white leather chair, lowered the rollercoaster-like safety harness over my torso, and carefully weighed options on the console in front of me.</p>
<pre><code class="language-bash">&gt; Evening . . . . . . . . 20/person
&gt; Overnight . . . . . . . 100/person
&gt; Weekend . . . . . . . . 250/person
&gt; Week (BEST VALUE!)  . . 5000/family (Limit: 5)
</code></pre>
<p>I looked over my right shoulder to see my wife and kids’ anxious faces gleaming back at me, ready with the nervous energy of a thousand suns to embark on our well-earned vacation. It’s been awhile. Some rough, lean years working like hell but through sacrifices and extreme budgeting we had finally saved up enough.</p>
<p>I hesitated to tap the screen. A nervous laugh. A moment of internal calculus. Maybe a handful of evenings would be enough. Would it have the same effect? A couple weekends would surely be enough to reset. More economical. And then we’d have a little left over, just in case.</p>
<p>I sensed my wife’s mind-reading. I sensed her fear I would succumb to my inner self-doubt. She has been working the hardest for this. Sacrificing to create these memories. I needed to shake those miser habits we’ve formed out of years of austerity, what has become my identity.</p>
<p>“Oh, alright. Here we go,” I groaned and grimaced as I tapped the screen.</p>
<p>“You selected <code>One Week</code>” chimed the female voice of the console. Our chairs tilted slightly back, I felt the credits debit from my account, we were off. Finally.</p>
<p>The hiss of the pneumatic syringes, the sting on the spinal column, the cool and heavy breeze of the sedatives, the warm cocktail of endorphins and dopamine to stimulate our deepest dreams and desires, the chairs and harnesses catching our weight as we drifted away from consciousness. The lights in the room slowly dimmed. We would be back in a week.</p>
</description>

        <title>The Hexagons and the Hexa-nots</title>
        <description><p><tt>It’s a secret to everyone! This post is for RSS subscribers only.
<a href="https://daverupert.com/rss-club/">Read more about RSS Club</a>.
</tt></p>
<p>Twitter released a feature that allows you to connect your crypto wallet to your Twitter account. Once you connect your wallet, you can set your profile picture to an NFT that you own.</p>
<p>I mean… setting your profile picture (”pfp”) wasn’t a hard problem before. Right click &gt; Save As, right? But this feature eliminates your phone’s camera roll as a middleman and instead inserts your wallet and the OpenSeas API as two third-party middlemen instead. If you’re wealthy enough to own enough NFTs that you have a hard time managing them all as profile pics, I suppose this is useful.</p>
<p>Ok. Whatever. Then Twitter’s implementation took it a step further and when you add your NFT as a pfp (which you could do before), it added a hexagonal clipping mask to NFT profile pictures. Users that have NFTs get a hexagon, users that don’t get regular old circles. That distinction, that ability to broadcast status, is now coded into the entire application.</p>
<p>It’s weird. NFT pfps already had a strong sense of in-group membership and <a href="https://daverupert.com/2021/11/tf2-hats/">status performance</a>. You could already spot a crypto enthusiast by their gaudy, semi-generative, ape-themed or pixelated punk profile pic. Thousands of minted NFTs already had a consistent square format (for use as profile pictures) but Twitter added hexagons to the mix for… pizazz? As a watermark to assert ownership?</p>
<p>The crypto community is not short on memes and social signifiers: apes, whales, pixel punks, diamond hands, to the moon, laser eyes, “gm”, WAGMI, probably nothing, <code>.eth</code> usernames, and a slew of in-group words no one else uses like “airdrop”, “fiat”, “petrodollar”, etc. Plenty of indicators, why add another?</p>
<p>I shouldn’t get worked up about a shape, but what I specifically don’t like about the hexagons are that they create another form of “otherism”; haves and have-nots. HODLers and NGMIs. Two camps. In-group and out-group. It’s creating division in a place where the world didn’t need any help creating division. The world doesn’t need more <em>us</em> versus <em>them</em>, yet we willingly apply feature glitter to increse the divide.</p>
<p>Somewhat apropos to this whole situation we’ve found ourselves in, the hexagon is just a thin veneer of symbolism; a mask applied to the mundane giving it the appearance of something special. An illusion of value.</p>
<p>Transmitted via web2 for obvious reasons.</p>
</description>

        <title>The man playing the ukulele at the doctor’s office.</title>
        <description><p>I was leaving a doctor’s appointment and as I rounded the corner to the waiting room I could hear the dulcet tones of a ukulele, but it sounded close.</p>
<p>My first reaction was “What in the fuck is going on?” as I scanned the ceiling for the speaker where the Muzak was coming from. Then in the waiting room I saw an older white man with a ponytail and a Hawaiian shirt calmly strumming his ukulele.</p>
<p>Again, I reacted, “What the fuck is going on?”</p>
<p>Then I caught myself. This… is… weird.</p>
<p>Why was he playing it in the doctors office? Was he a minstrel? Was he calming the souls of fellow patients?  A minister? A minister to himself? Does he just love Hawaii and goddamn it ain’t no one gonna stop him not even the cops at the doctors office?</p>
<p>I think this moment struck me like a ton of bricks because it’s been awhile since I’ve encountered weird due to the pandemic. Angry? Oh, I’ve encountered plenty of angry. Hot-headed assholes losing their shit in a Chic-fil-A drive thru, yeah I’ve seen that, but been awhile since I’ve seen weird.</p>
<p>The world could use a little more weird.</p>
<p>I miss weird. I miss old Austin.</p>

        <title>HTML is general, ARIA is specific</title>
        <description><p>In <a href="https://open-ui.org/">Open UI</a> there’s been some discussion about <a href="https://github.com/openui/open-ui/issues/417">what default ARIA role the proposed <code>&lt;popupdialog&gt;</code> element should have</a>, if any…</p>
<p>The proposed <code>&lt;popupdialog&gt;</code> element is a top-layer element that anchors to another element. Semantically, that’s a lot like a <em>non-modal</em> <code>dialog</code>, but people will probably use it incorrectly as a <code>listbox</code>, <code>tooltip</code>, <code>combobox</code>, etc. which are not a <code>dialog</code> and have their own more appropriate semantics. Should it be a <code>dialog</code>? Or should it be nothing like a <code>&lt;div&gt;</code> or a <code>&lt;span&gt;</code> but sits on the top layer of a website? Should we have other (similar) elements for those specific use cases? Is <code>display: popup</code> the best primitive here?</p>
<p>All good questions and I’m sure someone smarter than me will provide an answer.</p>
<p>What struck me about it all was how ARIA wants to be specific. It asks elements “Who are you deep down in your soul?” It’s a sentry at the gate, asking elements to identify themselves and if the element belongs to or fits within the known lexicon then there are well-defined interaction patterns that work with the Assistive Technology. It’s all useful and makes sense if you consider aural interfaces.</p>
<p>HTML, in my view, tends to be more general and permissive. A chill uncle. <code>&lt;div&gt;</code>? Sure, that can be a <code>div</code>. <code>&lt;article&gt;</code>? If you think that’s the article, great, let’s start there. <code>&lt;video&gt;</code>? Sure, send me some sources and I’ll do my best otherwise I’ll do nothing. Did you use a link for a <code>&lt;button&gt;</code> and a <code>&lt;button&gt;</code> for a link? Aww geeze, Rick. Wish you hadn’t done that. There’s right and wrong ways to do HTML, but there’s often more than one path to a solution. HTML provides a lot of building blocks, spicy divs and spicy spans, sometimes with built-in functionality and semantics, and other times the functionality it’s all bring-your-own.</p>
<p>There’s a tension there, but I think that’s what you get in a robust language designed to be liberal in what it accepts but conservative in what it does.</p>
</description>
